ground_truth: Don removes his hat in a courtly bow, very much at ease with the apples, and then passes the ladies who are chatting, while one of them tsk-tsks, and they both look after Don as he sits on a bar stool, putting down the paper bag. He takes the bills and change from his pocket and puts it on the bar as Nat pours the drink and returns to squeezing lemons. Don picks up the glass and is suddenly acutely aware of the people at the table and Nat's eyes, which causes the glass to freeze halfway to his mouth. He puts it down and starts playing the nonchalant, casual drinker -- the man who can take it or leave it -- then takes a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, shakes one out, and lights it. As he puts the match in the ashtray, his eyes fall on that jigger of whiskey, so he puts the handkerchief back in his pocket, lifts the glass, and drains it in one gulp. Nat comes up with the bar towel to wipe off the wet ring left by the glass, while Don holds the empty jigger in his hand. From the table in the background, Gloria heads for the powder room, passing Don and running her finger through the neckline of his hair, then she goes on. Don turns back to Nat, points at the bag with the apples showing, but Nat looks and doesn't get it until Don, like a magician, takes two apples out, revealing the necks of the bottles, prompting Nat to pull one. Nat leans over the bar towards Don as he points to the empty glass for Nat to fill it, and without a change of expression, Nat pours the second drink. Gloria returns from the powder room, and on her way to her gentleman friend at the table, she runs her finger through the neckline of Don's hair. She is almost past him when he catches her hand and pulls her towards him, then Don looks off toward the table, and she returns to the table. The camera focuses on the wet rings the wet glass has left on the bar, and in two quick dissolves, we see the five rings, then six, then nine. He puts the robe with the slippers inside it into the case as Wick slams shut the suitcase and snaps the lock. Wick takes his suitcase and goes into the living room, followed by Helen, setting down the suitcase and taking a topcoat from the closet, while Helen turns away from Wick, leans against the wall, hoping he won't see that she's crying. Don, with an empty jigger in his hand, stands at the same spot, only now leaning with his back against the bar in a place about half filled with eight customers at the bar and five tables occupied.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Don doffs his cap in a gallant nod, quite at comfort with the apples, and then crosses the ladies who are conversing, while one of them clicks, and they both watch after Don as he perches on a bar stool, setting down the paper sack. He extracts the bills and coins from his pocket and places it on the bar as Nat pours the beverage and returns to pressing lemons. Don lifts the tumbler and is suddenly keenly conscious of the folks at the table and Nat's gaze, which causes the tumbler to halt midway to his lips. He sets it down and commences portraying the blasé, informal imbiber -- the man who can accept it or reject it -- then removes a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, shakes one out, and ignites it. As he places the match in the ashtray, his gaze falls on that jigger of whiskey, so he returns the handkerchief to his pocket, lifts the tumbler, and empties it in one swallow. Nat approaches with the bar cloth to clean off the moist circle left by the tumbler, while Don grasps the empty jigger in his hand. From the table in the backdrop, Gloria heads for the powder room, passing Don and tracing her finger through the neckline of his hair, then she moves on. Don turns back to Nat, gestures at the sack with the apples peeking, but Nat glances and doesn't comprehend until Don, like an illusionist, extracts two apples, revealing the necks of the bottles, prompting Nat to extract one. Nat leans over the bar towards Don as he indicates the empty tumbler for Nat to refill it, and without a shift of expression, Nat pours the subsequent drink. Gloria returns from the powder room, and on her way to her gentleman companion at the table, she traces her finger through the neckline of Don's hair. She is almost beyond him when he seizes her hand and draws her towards him, then Don glances off to the table, and she returns to the table. The camera focuses on the moist circles the damp tumbler has left on the bar, and in two swift transitions, we observe the five circles, then six, then nine. He places the robe with the slippers within it into the case as Wick snaps shut the suitcase and clicks the lock. Wick carries his suitcase and proceeds into the living room, followed by Helen, setting down the suitcase and taking an overcoat from the closet, while Helen turns away from Wick, leans against the wall, hoping he won't perceive that she's weeping. Don, with an empty jigger in his hand, stands at the identical spot, only now leaning with his back against the bar in a place about half occupied with eight patrons at the bar and five tables filled.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Don's hat is removed in a courtly bow, very much at ease with the apples, and then the ladies who are chatting are passed by him, while one of them tsk-tsks, and they both look after Don as a bar stool is sat on by him, putting down the paper bag. The bills and change are taken from his pocket and put on the bar by him as Nat pours the drink and returns to squeezing lemons. The glass is picked up by Don, and he is suddenly acutely aware of the people at the table and Nat's eyes, which cause the glass to freeze halfway to his mouth. It is put down by him, and the nonchalant, casual drinker -- the man who can take it or leave it -- is started to be played by him. Then a pack of cigarettes is taken from his pocket, one is shaken out and lit. As the match is put in the ashtray by him, his eyes fall on that jigger of whiskey, so the handkerchief is put back in his pocket by him, the glass is lifted, and it is drained in one gulp. The bar towel is brought up by Nat to wipe off the wet ring left by the glass, while the empty jigger is held in Don's hand. From the table in the background, Gloria heads for the powder room, passes Don and runs her finger through the neckline of his hair, then she goes on. Nat is turned back to by Don, the bag with the apples showing is pointed at by him, but Nat looks and doesn't get it until, like a magician, two apples are taken out by Don, revealing the necks of the bottles, prompting Nat to pull one. The bar is leaned over by Nat towards Don as the empty glass is pointed to by him for Nat to fill it, and without a change of expression, the second drink is poured by Nat. Gloria returns from the powder room, and on her way to her gentleman friend at the table, her finger is run through the neckline of Don's hair by her. She is almost past him when her hand is caught by him, and she is pulled towards him, then the table is looked off toward by Don, and she returns to the table. The wet rings the wet glass has left on the bar are focused on by the camera, and in two quick dissolves, we see the five rings, then six, then nine. The robe with the slippers inside it is put into the case as the suitcase is slammed shut by Wick and the lock is snapped. His suitcase is taken by Wick and he goes into the living room, followed by Helen, the suitcase being set down by her and a topcoat being taken from the closet, while away from Wick she turns, leans against the wall, and hopes that she won't be seen crying by him. Don, with an empty jigger in his hand, is standing at the same spot, only now he is leaning with his back against the bar in a place about half filled with eight customers at the bar and five tables occupied.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Don bows courteously, comfortable with the apples, and passes chatting ladies, one tsk-tsking as they watch him sit at the bar, placing a paper bag down. He takes out bills and change as Nat pours a drink and resumes squeezing lemons. Don lifts the glass, aware of the people and Nat's gaze, causing him to pause. He acts nonchalant, lights a cigarette, then drains the whiskey in one gulp. Nat wipes the wet ring left by the glass as Don holds the empty jigger. Gloria heads to the powder room, brushing Don's hairline with her finger. Don points at the apple bag, revealing bottle necks, prompting Nat to pour another drink. Gloria returns, brushes Don's hair again, and he briefly holds her hand before she returns to her table. The camera shows wet rings on the bar, increasing from five to nine. Wick packs a robe and slippers into a suitcase, snapping it shut, and moves to the living room with Helen, who turns away, hiding her tears. Don, with an empty jigger, leans against the bar in a half-filled room with eight bar customers and five occupied tables.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Don bows, hat in hand, then walks past chatting ladies—one tsking—as they watch him sit at the bar and set down a paper bag. He pulls out bills and change, placing them on the bar. Nat pours his drink and resumes squeezing lemons. Don lifts the glass but freezes, sensing the eyes from a table and Nat. He sets it down, acts casual, lights a cigarette, then pockets his handkerchief and downs the whiskey. Nat wipes the glass ring as Don holds the empty jigger. Gloria walks by to the powder room, running her finger along Don’s hairline. Don shows Nat apples in the bag, then reveals bottle necks, prompting Nat to pour another. Gloria returns, again brushing Don’s hair, but this time he grabs her hand before she moves on. The camera shows increasing glass rings—five, six, nine. Don packs a robe and slippers as Wick snaps his suitcase shut. Wick enters the living room with Helen, who grabs a topcoat and hides tears against the wall. Don, jigger in hand, leans against the bar, now half full with eight patrons and five occupied tables.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Don, with a graceful and courtly gesture, removes his hat and executes a bow, appearing completely at ease with the apples in his possession. He then proceeds to walk past the ladies who are engaged in conversation. One of them makes a disapproving "tsk-tsk" sound, and both women watch Don as he makes his way to a bar stool, where he places the paper bag down. He retrieves the bills and change from his pocket, placing them on the bar as Nat, the bartender, pours a drink and resumes squeezing lemons. Don picks up the glass, but suddenly becomes acutely aware of the people seated at the table and the watchful eyes of Nat, causing him to pause with the glass halfway to his mouth. He sets it down and adopts the demeanor of a nonchalant, casual drinker—the kind of man who can take or leave a drink—before taking a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, shaking one out, and lighting it. As he places the match in the ashtray, his gaze falls on the jigger of whiskey, prompting him to return the handkerchief to his pocket, lift the glass, and drain it in one swift gulp. Nat approaches with a bar towel to wipe away the wet ring left by the glass, while Don holds the empty jigger in his hand. From a table in the background, Gloria makes her way to the powder room, passing Don and playfully running her finger through the neckline of his hair before continuing on her way. Don turns back to Nat, gesturing towards the bag with the apples peeking out, but Nat doesn't understand until Don, like a magician performing a trick, pulls out two apples, revealing the necks of the bottles hidden beneath, prompting Nat to pull one out. Nat leans over the bar towards Don as he points to the empty glass, signaling for Nat to fill it, and without any change in expression, Nat pours a second drink. Gloria returns from the powder room, and as she heads back to her gentleman friend at the table, she once again runs her finger through the neckline of Don's hair. She is nearly past him when he catches her hand and gently pulls her towards him, then Don glances off towards the table, and she returns to her seat. The camera focuses on the wet rings left by the glass on the bar, and in two quick dissolves, we see the progression from five rings to six, and then to nine. Don places the robe, with the slippers tucked inside, into the case as Wick forcefully closes the suitcase and snaps the lock shut. Wick takes his suitcase and moves into the living room, with Helen following behind, setting down the suitcase and retrieving a topcoat from the closet. Meanwhile, Helen turns away from Wick, leaning against the wall, hoping he won't notice that she's crying. Don, still holding the empty jigger in his hand, remains in the same spot, now leaning with his back against the bar in a room that is about half full, with eight customers at the bar and five tables occupied.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Don, with a graceful and courtly gesture, gently removes his hat and executes a polite bow, appearing completely at ease with the apples in his possession. He then proceeds to leisurely walk past the ladies who are deeply engaged in conversation. One of them makes a disapproving "tsk-tsk" sound, and both women watch Don attentively as he makes his way to a bar stool, where he carefully places the paper bag down. He retrieves the bills and change from his pocket, laying them down on the bar as Nat, the bartender, skillfully pours a drink before resuming his task of squeezing lemons. Don picks up the glass, yet suddenly becomes acutely aware of the people seated at the table and the watchful eyes of Nat, causing him to pause with the glass poised halfway to his mouth. He sets it down, adopting the demeanor of a nonchalant, casual drinker—the kind of man who can take or leave a drink at will—before taking a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, shaking one out, and lighting it with a practiced ease. As he places the extinguished match in the ashtray, his gaze falls on the jigger of whiskey, prompting him to return the handkerchief to his pocket, lift the glass, and drain it in one swift, fluid motion. Nat approaches with a bar towel to wipe away the wet ring left by the glass, while Don holds the empty jigger in his hand with a certain deliberateness. From a table in the background, Gloria makes her way to the powder room, passing by Don and playfully running her finger through the neckline of his hair before continuing on her way. Don turns back to Nat, gesturing towards the bag with the apples peeking out, yet Nat doesn't comprehend until Don, like a magician performing a clever trick, pulls out two apples, revealing the necks of the bottles cunningly hidden beneath, prompting Nat to pull one out with interest. Nat leans over the bar towards Don as he points to the empty glass, signaling for Nat to fill it once more, and without any change in expression, Nat obliges by pouring a second drink. Gloria returns from the powder room, and as she heads back to her gentleman friend at the table, she once again runs her finger through the neckline of Don's hair. She is nearly past him when he gently catches her hand and softly pulls her towards him, then Don glances off towards the table, and she returns to her seat with a sense of amused compliance. The camera focuses closely on the wet rings left by the glass on the bar, and in a series of two quick dissolves, we observe the progression from five rings to six, and then to nine. Don places the robe, with the slippers neatly tucked inside, into the case as Wick forcefully closes the suitcase and snaps the lock shut with a definitive click. Wick takes hold of his suitcase and moves deliberately into the living room, with Helen trailing closely behind him, setting down the suitcase and retrieving a topcoat from the closet. Meanwhile, Helen turns away from Wick, leaning against the wall, hoping beyond hope that he won't notice that she's quietly crying. Don, still holding the empty jigger in his hand, remains in the exact same spot, now leaning with his back comfortably against the bar in a room that is about half full, with eight customers seated at the bar and five tables occupied throughout the space.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Don, with a graceful and confident motion, removes his hat in a courtly bow, feeling completely at ease with the apples he carries. He then walks past the ladies who are engaged in conversation, one of whom expresses mild disapproval with a tsk-tsk, while both women watch him as he proceeds to sit on a bar stool, carefully placing the paper bag beside him. Reaching into his pocket, he retrieves the bills and change, placing them on the bar just as Nat, the bartender, pours his drink and resumes the task of squeezing lemons. Don picks up the glass, but as he becomes suddenly and intensely aware of the people seated at the table and the watchful eyes of Nat, he hesitates, the glass pausing midway to his lips. Opting for a more casual demeanor, he sets the glass down and adopts the persona of a nonchalant drinker, the kind of man who can take or leave a drink. He then retrieves a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, expertly shakes one out, and lights it. After extinguishing the match in the ashtray, his gaze falls upon the jigger of whiskey, prompting him to return the handkerchief to his pocket, lift the glass, and consume its contents in a single, decisive gulp. Nat approaches with a bar towel to wipe away the wet ring left by the glass, while Don holds the now-empty jigger in his hand. From a table in the background, Gloria makes her way to the powder room, passing Don and playfully running her finger through the neckline of his hair before continuing on her way. Don turns his attention back to Nat, gesturing towards the bag with the apples peeking out, but Nat remains puzzled until Don, with a flourish akin to a magician's trick, extracts two apples, revealing the necks of hidden bottles, prompting Nat to pull one out. Leaning over the bar towards Don, Nat acknowledges the empty glass that Don points to, and without altering his expression, Nat pours a second drink. Gloria returns from the powder room, and as she heads back to her gentleman friend at the table, she once again runs her finger through the neckline of Don's hair. Just as she is about to pass him, Don catches her hand and gently pulls her towards him, then glances towards the table, prompting her to return to her seat. The camera shifts focus to the wet rings left by the glass on the bar, and through two quick dissolves, the number of rings increases from five to six, then to nine. Meanwhile, Wick places a robe with slippers inside a suitcase, slamming it shut and snapping the lock. He carries the suitcase into the living room, followed by Helen, who sets down the suitcase and retrieves a topcoat from the closet. Helen turns away from Wick, leaning against the wall, hoping to conceal her tears. Don, still holding the empty jigger, remains in the same spot, now leaning with his back against the bar in a room that is about half full, with eight customers at the bar and five tables occupied.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Don removes his hat with a courtly bow, passing the chatting ladies who watch him as he sits at the bar and places a paper bag down. He takes out some bills and change, setting them on the bar as Nat pours his drink and resumes squeezing lemons. Don, aware of the people around him and Nat's gaze, hesitates before putting the glass down, adopting a casual demeanor. He lights a cigarette, then, drawn back to the whiskey, puts away his handkerchief, lifts the glass, and drinks it in one gulp. Nat wipes the bar as Don holds the empty glass. Gloria heads to the powder room, brushing her finger through Don's hair as she passes. Don gestures to the bag, revealing bottles hidden beneath apples, prompting Nat to pour another drink. Gloria returns, again running her finger through Don's hair, but he catches her hand briefly before she returns to her table. The camera shows the increasing number of wet rings left by Don's glass on the bar. Meanwhile, Wick packs a robe and slippers into a suitcase, snapping it shut, and moves to the living room with Helen, who turns away to hide her tears. Don remains at the bar, now leaning against it, surrounded by other patrons.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Don, who displays a level of grace reminiscent of a bygone era, removes his hat in a courtly bow, very much at ease with the apples, which are a staple of the region and symbolize abundance, and then passes the ladies who are chatting, while one of them tsk-tsks, and they both look after Don as he sits on a bar stool, putting down the paper bag. This paper bag, often used by locals to discreetly carry goods, reveals a hint of his intentions. He takes the bills and change from his pocket, a gesture indicating both readiness and the casual nature of repeat visits, and puts it on the bar as Nat pours the drink, a classic whiskey, and returns to squeezing lemons, likely for the cocktail of a nearby patron. Don picks up the glass and is suddenly acutely aware of the people at the table, regulars eyeing newcomers with curiosity, and Nat's eyes, which causes the glass to freeze halfway to his mouth. He puts it down and starts playing the nonchalant, casual drinker -- the man who can take it or leave it -- then takes a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, a brand known for its smooth flavor, shakes one out, and lights it. As he puts the match in the ashtray, an ashtray branded with the bar’s logo, his eyes fall on that jigger of whiskey, so he puts the handkerchief back in his pocket, lifts the glass, and drains it in one gulp. Nat, a seasoned bartender known for his discretion, comes up with the bar towel to wipe off the wet ring left by the glass, while Don holds the empty jigger in his hand. From the table in the background, Gloria, a woman known for her effervescent personality, heads for the powder room, passing Don and running her finger through the neckline of his hair, then she goes on. Don turns back to Nat, points at the bag with the apples showing, but Nat looks and doesn't get it until Don, like a magician with a clever flourish, takes two apples out, revealing the necks of the bottles, prompting Nat to pull one. Nat leans over the bar towards Don as he points to the empty glass for Nat to fill it, and without a change of expression, a practiced poker face developed from years behind the bar, Nat pours the second drink. Gloria returns from the powder room, her preferred retreat for reapplying makeup, and on her way to her gentleman friend at the table, she again runs her finger through the neckline of Don's hair. She is almost past him when he catches her hand, a gesture that speaks of unspoken familiarity, and pulls her towards him, then Don looks off toward the table, and she returns to the table. The camera focuses on the wet rings the wet glass has left on the bar, and in two quick dissolves, we see the five rings, then six, then nine, a visual metaphor for the passage of time and increasing consumption. He puts the robe with the slippers inside it, essentials for comfort, into the case as Wick slams shut the suitcase and snaps the lock, indicating finality. Wick, a man of action, takes his suitcase and goes into the living room, followed by Helen, setting down the suitcase and taking a topcoat from the closet, a sign of impending departure, while Helen turns away from Wick, leans against the wall, hoping he won't see that she's crying, her tears a silent testament to unresolved emotions. Don, with an empty jigger in his hand, stands at the same spot, only now leaning with his back against the bar in a place about half filled with eight customers at the bar and five tables occupied, capturing the lively yet intimate atmosphere of the establishment.

On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. Nat leans over the bar towards Don as he points to the empty glass for Nat to fill it and without a change of expression Nat pours the second drink. Gloria returns from the powder room and on her way to her gentleman friend at the table she runs her finger through the neckline of Don's hair. She is almost past him when he catches her hand and pulls her towards him. then Don looks off toward the table and she returns to the table. The camera focuses on the wet rings. the wet glass has left on the bar and in two quick dissolves we see the five rings then six then nine. He puts the robe with the slippers inside it into the case as Wick slams shut the suitcase and snaps the lock. Wick takes his suitcase and goes into the living room followed by Helen setting down the suitcase and taking a topcoat from the closet. while Helen turns away from. Wick leans against the wall hoping he will not see that she is crying. Don with an empty jigger in his hand stands at the same spot only now leaning with his back against the bar in a place about half filled with eight customers at the bar and five tables occupied.

test_cases.description: Don removes his hat in a courtly bow very much at ease with the apples and then passes the ladies who are chatting while one of them tsktsks and they both look after Don as he sits on a bar stool putting down the paper bag. He takes the bills and change from his pocket and puts it on the bar as Nat pours the drink and returns to squeezing lemons. while Helen turns away from. test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: Jerry removes his hat in a courtly bow, very much at ease with the apples, and then passes the seagulls who are chatting, while one of them tsk-tsks, and they both look after Jerry as he sits on a bar stool, putting down the paper bag. He takes the bills and change from his pocket and puts it on the bar as Lucy pours the drink and returns to squeezing lemons. Jerry picks up the glass and is suddenly acutely aware of the people at the table and Lucy's eyes, which causes the glass to freeze halfway to his mouth. He puts it down and starts playing the nonchalant, casual drinker -- the man who can take it or leave it -- then takes a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, shakes one out, and lights it. As he puts the match in the ashtray, his eyes fall on that jigger of whiskey, so he puts the handkerchief back in his pocket, lifts the glass, and drains it in one gulp. Lucy comes up with the bar towel to wipe off the wet ring left by the glass, while Jerry holds the empty jigger in his hand. From the table in the background, a raccoon heads for the powder room, passing Jerry and running her finger through the neckline of his hair, then she goes on. Jerry turns back to Lucy, points at the bag with the apples showing, but Lucy looks and doesn't get it until Jerry, like a magician, takes two apples out, revealing the necks of the bottles, prompting Lucy to pull one. Lucy leans over the bar towards Jerry as he points to the empty glass for Lucy to fill it, and without a change of expression, Lucy pours the second drink. The raccoon returns from the powder room, and on her way to her gentleman friend at the table, she runs her finger through the neckline of Jerry's hair. She is almost past him when he catches her hand and pulls her towards him, then Jerry looks off toward the table, and she returns to the table. The camera focuses on the wet rings the wet glass has left on the bar, and in two quick dissolves, we see the five rings, then six, then nine. He puts the robe with the slippers inside it into the case as a bear slams shut the suitcase and snaps the lock. The bear takes his suitcase and goes into the living room, followed by a penguin, setting down the suitcase and taking a topcoat from the closet, while the penguin turns away from the bear, leans against the wall, hoping he won't see that she's crying. Jerry, with an empty jigger in his hand, stands at the same spot, only now leaning with his back against the bar in a place about half filled with eight customers at the bar and five tables occupied.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Don removes his cap in a courtly bow, very much at ease with the oranges, and then passes the gentlemen who are chatting, while one of them tsk-tsks, and they both look after Don as he sits on a piano bench, putting down the leather pouch. He takes the coins and tickets from his pocket and puts them on the counter as Nat pours the soda and returns to slicing cucumbers. Don picks up the cup and is suddenly acutely aware of the artists at the easel and Nat's eyes, which causes the cup to freeze halfway to his mouth. He puts it down and starts playing the nonchalant, casual drinker -- the man who can take it or leave it -- then takes a deck of playing cards from his pocket, shakes one out, and fans it. As he puts the matchbook in the treacle bowl, his eyes fall on that jigger of juice, so he puts the kerchief back in his pocket, lifts the cup, and drains it in one gulp. Nat comes up with the washcloth to wipe off the wet ring left by the cup, while Don holds the empty jigger in his hand. From the easel in the background, Gloria heads for the cloakroom, passing Don and running her finger through the sleeve of his sweater, then she goes on. Don turns back to Nat, points at the pouch with the oranges showing, but Nat looks and doesn't get it until Don, like a magician, takes two oranges out, revealing the necks of the thermoses, prompting Nat to pull one. Nat leans over the counter towards Don as he points to the empty cup for Nat to fill it, and without a change of expression, Nat pours the second beverage. Gloria returns from the cloakroom, and on her way to her gentleman friend at the easel, she runs her finger through the sleeve of Don's sweater. She is almost past him when he catches her hand and pulls her towards him, then Don looks off toward the easel, and she returns to the easel. The camera focuses on the wet rings the wet cup has left on the counter, and in two quick dissolves, we see the five rings, then six, then nine. He puts the scarf with the mittens inside it into the basket as Wick slams shut the suitcase and snaps the lock. Wick takes his suitcase and goes into the study, followed by Helen, setting down the suitcase and taking a cardigan from the drawer, while Helen turns away from Wick, leans against the bookshelf, hoping he won't see that she's crying. Don, with an empty jigger in his hand, stands at the same spot, only now leaning with his back against the counter in a place about half filled with eight patrons at the counter and five platforms occupied.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Don spins his hat in a playful twirl, very much at ease with the apples, and then strolls past the ladies who are whispering, while one of them nods, and they both glance after Don as he perches on a bar stool, placing down the paper bag. He fetches the bills and change from his pocket and sets it on the bar as Nat examines the drink and transitions to stacking lemons. Don raises the glass and is suddenly highly conscious of the people at the table and Nat's stare, which makes the glass hover midway to his mouth. He sets it down and starts portraying the aloof, indifferent drinker -- the man who could take it or leave it -- then extracts a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, dislodges one, and ignites it. As he drops the match in the ashtray, his gaze lands on that jigger of whiskey, so he tucks the handkerchief back in his pocket, raises the glass, and empties it in one swift motion. Nat approaches with the bar towel to polish off the damp ring left by the glass, while Don holds the void jigger in his hand. From the table in the background, Gloria drifts toward the powder room, passing Don and brushing her finger across the edge of his hair, then she proceeds. Don turns back to Nat, gestures at the bag with the apples peeking out, but Nat peers and doesn't grasp it until Don, like a conjurer, extracts two apples, uncovering the necks of the bottles, prompting Nat to select one. Nat leans over the bar towards Don as he signals to the vacant glass for Nat to replenish it, and with an unchanged expression, Nat serves the second drink. Gloria reappears from the powder room, and on her way to her gentleman friend at the table, she brushes her finger through the edge of Don's hair. She is nearly past him when he seizes her hand and draws her near him, then Don glances off toward the table, and she heads back to the table. The camera centers on the damp rings the wet glass has rendered on the bar, and in two swift transitions, we see the five rings, then six, then nine. He stashes the robe with the slippers inside it into the case as Wick firmly closes the suitcase and secures the lock. Wick carries his suitcase and proceeds into the living room, accompanied by Helen, placing down the suitcase and retrieving a topcoat from the closet, while Helen averts her gaze from Wick, leans against the wall, hoping he won't notice that she's crying. Don, with an unoccupied jigger in his hand, stands at the same spot, only now resting with his back against the bar in a place about half filled with eight patrons at the bar and five tables occupied.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Bill removes his glove in a graceful bow, very much at ease with the oranges, and then passes the gentlemen who are laughing, while one of them chuckles, and they both look after Bill as he sits on a couch, putting down the shoebox. He takes the coins and tokens from his pocket and puts it on the counter as Max pours the coffee and returns to slicing cucumbers. Bill picks up the cup and is suddenly acutely aware of the cats on the chair and Max's gaze, which causes the cup to freeze halfway to his lips. He puts it down and starts playing the aloof, casual sipper -- the woman who can take it or leave it -- then takes a roll of tape from his pocket, shakes one out, and unwinds it. As he puts the clip in the bin, his eyes fall on that cup of tea, so he puts the scarf back in his pocket, lifts the cup, and drains it in one gulp. Max comes up with the rag to wipe off the wet circle left by the cup, while Bill holds the empty mug in his hand. From the chair in the background, Laura heads for the mirror, passing Bill and running her hand through the part of his sweater, then she goes on. Bill turns back to Max, points at the shoebox with the oranges showing, but Max looks and doesn't get it until Bill, like an illusionist, takes two oranges out, revealing the tops of the cans, prompting Max to pull one. Max leans over the counter towards Bill as he points to the empty mug for Max to fill it, and without a change of demeanor, Max pours the second coffee. Laura returns from the mirror, and on her way to her lady friend at the chair, she runs her hand through the part of Bill's sweater. She is almost past him when he catches her arm and pulls her towards him, then Bill looks off toward the chair, and she returns to the chair. The camera focuses on the wet circles the wet cup has left on the counter, and in two quick dissolves, we see the three circles, then four, then seven. He puts the jacket with the gloves inside it into the bag as Joe slams shut the backpack and snaps the buckle. Joe takes his backpack and goes into the dining room, followed by Sarah, setting down the backpack and taking a cardigan from the shelf, while Sarah turns away from Joe, leans against the window, hoping he won't see that she's laughing. Bill, with an empty mug in his hand, stands at the same spot, only now leaning with his back against the counter in a place about half filled with twelve customers at the counter and eight chairs occupied.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Tom doffs his cap with an exaggerated flourish, feeling quite comfortable with the oranges, and then strolls past the gentlemen who are laughing, while one of them chuckles, and they both watch after Tom as he perches on a bar stool, setting down the paper bag. He retrieves the receipts and coins from his pocket and places them on the bar as Mike brews the coffee and resumes chopping limes. Tom lifts the mug and is suddenly keenly aware of the guests at the table and Mike's gaze, which causes the mug to halt midway to his lips. He sets it down and begins performing the composed, relaxed diner -- the guy who can enjoy or refuse it -- then takes a deck of cards from his pocket, extracts one, and examines it. As he places the card in the ashtray, his eyes land on that piece of pie, so he puts the scarf back in his pocket, picks up the fork, and devours it in one bite. Mike approaches with the bar towel to clean off the sticky ring left by the mug, while Tom holds the empty fork in his hand. From the table in the background, Clara heads for the powder room, passing Tom and brushing her finger through the edge of his collar, then she continues. Tom turns back to Mike, gestures at the bag with the oranges showing, but Mike observes and doesn't get it until Tom, like a magician, extracts two oranges, unveiling the necks of the bottles, prompting Mike to grab one. Mike leans over the bar towards Tom as he gestures to the empty mug for Mike to fill it, and without changing his expression, Mike brews the second coffee. Clara returns from the powder room, and on her way to her companion at the table, she brushes her finger through the edge of Tom's collar. She is nearly past him when he catches her hand and draws her closer, then Tom glances off toward the table, and she returns to the table. The camera focuses on the sticky rings the mug has left on the bar, and in two quick dissolves, we see the two rings, then three, then six. He places the jacket with the socks inside it into the case as Jack snaps shut the suitcase and secures the lock. Jack grabs his suitcase and enters the living room, followed by Sarah, setting down the suitcase and removing a trench coat from the closet, while Sarah turns away from Jack, leans against the wall, wishing he won't notice that she's upset. Tom, with an empty fork in his hand, stands at the same spot, only now reclining with his back against the bar in a place about half filled with fifteen patrons at the bar and seven tables occupied.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Don removes his cap in a respectful nod, very much at ease with the oranges, and then passes the ladies who are whispering, while one of them shakes her head, and they both glance after Don as he reclines on a park bench, setting down the cloth sack. He pulls the receipts and coins from his pouch and places them on the counter as Nat mixes the cocktail and resumes peeling grapes. Don grips the mug and is suddenly hyper-aware of the folks at the booth and Nat's stare, which causes the mug to hover halfway to his lips. He sets it aside and starts assuming the façade of the indifferent, laid-back drinker -- the fellow who can indulge or abstain -- then retrieves a deck of cards from his pouch, fans one out, and flips it. As he tosses the matchstick in the wastebin, his eyes settle on that shot of rum, so he puts the scarf back in his pouch, lifts the mug, and downs it in one go. Nat approaches with the dish towel to scrub the damp mark left by the mug, while Don clutches the empty shot glass in his hand. From the booth in the backdrop, Gloria heads for the ladies' lounge, passing Don and brushing her thumb along the hem of his collar, then she moves on. Don turns back to Nat, gestures at the sack with the oranges peeking out, but Nat glances and doesn’t understand until Don, like a wizard, extracts two oranges, uncovering the necks of the jars, prompting Nat to tug one. Nat leans over the counter towards Don as he gestures to the empty mug for Nat to replenish it, and without a shift in demeanor, Nat mixes the subsequent cocktail. Gloria returns from the ladies' lounge, and on her way to her companion at the booth, she brushes her thumb along the hem of Don's collar. She is nearly past him when he grasps her hand and draws her toward him, then Don glances off toward the booth, and she returns to the booth. The camera highlights the damp marks the moist mug has left on the counter, and in two quick fades, we witness the four marks, then five, then eight. He places the cloak with the sandals inside it into the bag as Wick bangs shut the bag and snaps the clasp. Wick carries his bag into the den, followed by Helen, placing the bag and retrieving a raincoat from the wardrobe, while Helen turns aside from Wick, rests against the shelf, hoping he won't notice that she's weeping. Don, with an empty shot glass in his hand, stands at the identical place, only now leaning with his shoulder against the counter in a venue about half filled with ten patrons at the counter and seven booths occupied.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Danny adjusts his scarf with a graceful nod, quite at home among the oranges, and then strolls past the gentlemen who are debating, while one of them chuckles, and they both watch Danny as he perches on a lounge chair, placing down the picnic basket. He extracts the stamps and postcards from his wallet and lays them on the counter as Ned brews the tea and returns to peeling bananas. Danny lifts the cup and is suddenly intensely conscious of the pigeons on the bench and Ned's gaze, which causes the cup to hover halfway to his chin. He sets it back and begins performing as the disinterested, casual sipper—the kind who can sip or skip it—then retrieves a deck of cards from his wallet, flips one out, and tosses it. As he drops the deck in the bin, his eyes catch that vial of soda, so he tucks the napkin back in his wallet, raises the cup, and empties it in one swig. Ned approaches with the dishcloth to tidy up the damp blot left by the cup, while Danny clutches the empty vial in his palm. From the bench nearby, Glenda strolls to the powder room, passing Danny and tracing her finger through the cuff of his sleeve, then she continues. Danny turns back to Ned, gestures at the basket with the oranges peeking, but Ned looks and doesn't grasp it until Danny, like a conjurer, removes two oranges, revealing the tops of the cans, prompting Ned to seize one. Ned bends over the counter towards Danny as he gestures to the vacant cup for Ned to fill it, and without a flicker of expression, Ned brews the second tea. Glenda returns from the powder room, and on her walk to her dance partner at the bench, she traces her finger through the cuff of Danny's sleeve. She is nearly past him when he clasps her hand and draws her toward him, then Danny glances toward the bench, and she moves back to the bench. The camera lingers on the damp blots the moist cup has left on the counter, and in two brisk fades, we count the seven blots, then eight, then eleven. He places the jacket with the boots inside it into the bag as Will slams shut the briefcase and clicks the latch. Will takes his briefcase and steps into the den, trailed by Hazel, setting down the briefcase and retrieving a raincoat from the locker, while Hazel turns away from Will, leans against the bookshelf, hoping he won't notice that she's upset. Danny, with an empty vial in his palm, stands at the same spot, only now leaning with his back against the counter in a space about half filled with ten patrons at the counter and seven benches occupied.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Don removes his hat, passes chatting ladies, and sits at the bar, placing a paper bag down. He takes a drink, aware of the people around him, and tries to appear nonchalant. Lighting a cigarette, he is drawn back to the whiskey and downs it. Nat wipes the bar as Don reveals bottles hidden among apples in the bag, prompting Nat to pour another drink. Gloria passes, touches Don's hair, and returns to her table. As wet rings multiply on the bar, we see Don with an empty jigger while the bar fills with customers. Wick and Helen are in another room; Wick packs a suitcase while Helen turns to hide her tears. Don remains at the bar with eight customers and five tables occupied.
